title-group.article-title: The "Narrative is Travel" Metaphor: Between Spatial Sequence and Open Consequence

ref.mixed-citation: Adams, both the literary travel story and the modem novel are based on an "imaginative reshaping of reality" (134)
"a conflict and an al- liance between realism and romance," between truth claims and imagination (108-109)
Chupeau
Georges Van Den Abbeele argues in his Travel as Metaphor (1992)
Thus "the structure of the metaphor be- comes the metaphor for the travel of meaning" (xxiii).
Fludernik 20

"L'espace du roman" [The Space of the Novel], Butor also emphasizes the thematic affin- ity between the experience of distant places in travel and the literary imagination: "Toute fiction s'in- scrit done en notre espace comme voyage, et l'on peut dire à cet égard que c'est là le thème fondamental de toute littérature romanesque; tout roman qui nous raconte un voyage est donc plus clair, plus explicite que celui qui n'est pas capable d'exprimer métaphoriquement cette distance entre le lieu de la lecture et celui où nous emmène le récit" [All fiction thus inscribes itself in our space as travel, and we may say that this is the fundamental theme in all prose fiction; any novel that tells us about a journey is clearer and more explicit than novels that cannot metaphorically express the distance between the place of reading and the place where the story takes us] (50)
Montalbetti (100-120)
Roman Jakobson argued, for instance, that travelogues, as a kind of transitional genre, served an important function in the development of the modern novel (45).

Todorov, for instance, sees that temporal order and causality are closely linked and easily confused and further that "the logical series is in the reader's eyes a much stronger relation than the temporal series; if the two go together, he sees only the first" (42).
Rimmon-Kenan, in turn, temporal suc- cession is a sufficient condition for a narrative since "causality can often (always?) be projected onto temporality" (18)
Genette 80

Gibson's insights that the various spaces in The Odyssey are rigorously separated but "cannot be reduced to any homogeneous or global whole," or that "the mythical adventure of Odysseus is nothing more or less than the connecting up of these incommensurable spaces," are in line with the idea of the incompa- rable maps (17).
Ryan 2003
Jacob 247-251
Thacker for an analysis on the symbolic differences in the maps of the various editions of the book (the editions of 1936

Philippe Dubois has suggested that for Michel Butor the map, as a form of an inscribed world, or the world as an open catalogue/dictionary, is an inexhaustible reserve of readable signs in which one can invest interest and meaning (151)
Greene in Journey Without Maps
"more than I could say" (20)
"one's place in time" (19)
Greene's own Africanism, meaning the frequent superimposition of notions of childhood and primitive virtue on African spaces-"a quality of dark- ness is needed, of the inexplicable" (20)
Thacker 19-20
"that there is something that needs to be explained" (84)
Thacker 21-25
Mieke Bal's distinction between "frame-space" and "thematized space," the first meaning the place of action and the latter meaning "acting place" or space transformed into a story (136)

"become unified only through the voyager's journeying, when seen by him in the light of his progress: it is the panorama, in the last analysis, that acquires significance, and the voyager as such only through his passage as traveller. Yet the panorama is only present in so far as the traveler moved through it and recorded his experience" (89)
